Award.AwardTitle: Connecticut Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project combines efforts of the EDUCATION CONNECTION Center for 21st Century Skills with the Education Development Center (its research partner), and K-12 school districts to develop, implement, study, and evaluate an innovative STEM career academy model. A consortium of state colleges and universities (as well as other entities) helps to fully integrate cyberlearning and content courses in STEM with digital arts and media. The consortium includes Southern Connecticut (CT) State University, CT College of Technology, CT Office for Workforce Competitiveness, CT State Department of Education, and CT Pre-Engineering Program. This group intends to significantly increase the career interests of underrepresented students and improve their readiness for college-level coursework in STEM and ICT fields.

Prior NSF-funded projects and existing state supported programs (e.g. ATE project and Connecticut Career Choices or CCC) contribute to the foundation for the proposed Connecticut Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences (DAS Academy) project. Together, the partnership expands the focus from six high schools in 2002 to over 30 high schools in 2010.

Interactive online STEM/ICT coursework reaches over 1,200 students. Forty percent of these students are minorities. Students in the DAS Academy will be selected from four urban, four suburban and four rural high schools. The DAS Academy offers eligible students up to 15 college credits through the CT community colleges and universities. Participating teachers receive intensive professional development to advance skills and knowledge in STEM/ICT education, technology-rich instruction and 21st Century workforce standards. These skills help teachers guide students through the online coursework.

POR.DRECONTENT:
EDUCATION CONNECTION’s Center for 21st Century Skills, in collaboration with research partner Education Development Center (EDC) and a dedicated consortium including Southern Connecticut (CT) State University, CT College of Technology, CT Office for Workforce Competitiveness, CT State Department of Education (CSDE), CT Pre-Engineering Program, and diverse K-12 school district partners, developed, implemented, and evaluated an NSF ITEST Strategies Project, The Connecticut Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences (DAS Academy).  This Strategies Project further developed, implemented, studied, and evaluated an innovative STEM Career Academy Model that fully integrates cyberlearning and content courses in math,

science, digital arts/media, and technology to increase underrepresented students’ STEM and ICT career interest and improves readiness for college-level coursework in these fields. The project contributes to the research knowledge base about STEM education.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

STEM Academic Courses were delivered in a “blended learning” environment, including online and in-person instruction in the classroom.  As part of the integrated curriculum, thousands of high school students and teachers participated in authentic learning experiences in class, on college campuses, and at industry sites to strengthen interest and commitment to pursuing STEM-related college degrees and careers.  A culminating STEM challenge project was evaluated annually at the Student Innovation Exposition. Replicable strategies include the integration of the Academy in high schools serving a large proportion of minority students; ongoing interaction among students, educators, and STEM professionals; the incentive of earning college credit while in high school; and intensive professional development for educators.  Funding allowed for the expansion of the Academy with three additional courses: Algebra21, Geometry21, and Game Design & Development.

Major Accomplishments included:

Complete Development of DAS Academy Curriculum.  New courses developed, piloted, and evaluated were:  Algebra21, Geometry21, and Game Design & Development

Provide experiential learning for students and teachers at CT College and corporate campus locations.

Experiential Learning. Experiential learning took place at various industry and academic sites for all students.  An annual culminating Student Innovation Exposition showcased the work of the students. 

Teacher Professional Development.  Three summer institutes, serving over 150 teachers with over 600 complementary in-class/on-site coaching and mentoring sessions were completed.

Program Evaluation. Formative and summative evaluation assessed findings to improve effectiveness of program model.

BROADER IMPACTS:

Over the course of the 3-year funding period, the DAS Academy served a diverse group of students from urban and suburban schools. Students participating in either the full Academy or individual courses or programs numbered over 6000.  Of those students, 47% were female and 53% were male. In terms of ethnicity, 1% were American Indian, 4% were Asian American, 18% were African American, 15% were Latino, 6% listed as ‘other’, <1% were Pacific Islander, 55% were Caucasian. 47% were underrepresented by gender; 41% of students were underrepresented by ethnicity; 40% of students received free or reduced lunch.
